The United States must remain steadfast in our support for Israel, our most important ally and a beacon of democracy in the region, and stand with them at the United Nations -- as we have throughout history. I was appalled by the Security Council resolution last month which undermined the Israeli-Palestinian peace process and risked destabilizing an already volatile region with its dangerous and dishonest rhetoric. I voted in favor of today’s House resolution to stand in solidarity with our critical ally and to protect America's security.

I held a roundtable today with health care professionals, advocates, and Fifth District residents to discuss important provisions of the Affordable Care Act, necessary changes and improvements to the law, and the dangerous impact of repealing it without a sensible replacement. As I've said, the ACA has plenty that's good in it, and plenty, like the medical device and Cadillac taxes, that needs fixing. My view comes down to this: Fix it, don't repeal it without a solution in place. I encourage anyone--Democrat, Republican, or Independent--who has ideas to improve health care affordability and access to contact me; I look forward to working together. You can call my office at 888-216-5646 or go to gottheimer.house.gov. I'm eager to hear from you.

Earlier today, I heard from health care professionals and advocates about how we need to fix the Affordable Care Act while keeping what works. I want to hear from you, too. Please let me know what ideas you have to improve health care affordability and access and how to improve the ACA.

I held roundtable today with providers, doctors, hospitals, advocates, and other stakeholders on how we improve and fix the Affordable Care Act. We discussed the Cadillac tax, mental health parity, telemedicine, improving patient outcomes, and many other aspects of this issue. The consensus was that we need to fix the Affordable Care Act, but that we can't just abandon the law without an alternate plan. Over 700,000 New Jersey residents have health coverage through this law, and it has some important provisions like allowing those with preexisting conditions to get coverage and letting young adults stay on their parents' plans for longer. We need to work together to make changes and improvements to the ACA, not repeal it without a solution in place.

We pause today celebrate the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. His whole being was about reaching out to those with different views and trying to help them see the light of equality, of justice, and of opportunity for all. Dr. King urged us to embrace them in our common humanity -- all in pursuit of building, as it said in the preamble of our Constitution, that more perfect union.  While Dr. King urged us to embrace those with whom we disagree and to show them the light, he also taught us to fight back and hold the line. We must never give up. As he so wisely said 'Our lives begin to end the day we become silent about things that matter.' And I for one, will not be silent about the things that matter. I hope you will join me in making your voice heard.  Working together, I am confident that our best days will always be ahead of us, and Dr. King's famous dream will become a reality.

He also talked about increased costs for seniors -- stating that insurance premiums could rise five-fold for the seniors -- and millennials, an age group that is "most likely" to be hit with a 30 percent surcharge for coverage lapses as a result of moving, changing jobs or being removed from their parent's insurance.

WATCH LIVE:  It's National Police Week.   I'm with Congressman Bill Pascrell, Count Executive Jim Tedesco, Paramus Mayor Richard LaBarbiera, and the Police Benevolent Association's Charlie Schwartz, saying thank you to the men and women who keep our communities safe and especially to honor those who paid the ultimate price in their efforts to do so.  Today, we honor in particular the three officers who perished in the line of duty from the Police Department here in Paramus: Lieutenant Harry Carlough, Patrolman Michael McEllen, and Patrolman Vincent Brock.  We must never forget their bravery, service, and sacrifice.  Already this year, 48 police officers have died in the line of duty across the United States.  As we remember and honor them, we are reminded of just how much we owe to the men and women who put their lives on the lines every day to keep our families safe.  We cannot repay the debt our communities owe to these heroes and their families. There is no commitment I take more seriously than having the backs of our nation’s first responders and heroes.  Our police officers and all first responders can’t protect us without the resources they need to do their job safely and effectively.  The Paramus Police Department understands this.  In 2014, they received a $600,000 grant through the Department of Justice’s Community Oriented Policing Services, or COPS, grant program. At the time, Paramus did not have a Member of Congress who was willing to advocate on their behalf to the federal government to secure funds like these. But they were lucky enough to have a neighbor in Congressman Bill Pascrell, Jr. to fight to get them those resources that allowed them to hire five officers.  Well, I’m pleased to report that Paramus’ current Member of Congress has a different position from his predecessor on this issue.You now have a friend and a tireless champion.  I am committed to doing everything I can to make sure our law enforcement officers, and all first responders, get the resources they need to do their jobs effectively. And I will work to claw back every possible nickel from our federal taxes to help protect our communities and keep them safe from crime and terror.  It’s thanks to the protection first responders provide that people raise their families here and we must make sure it stays that way.

Compound taxes with the high cost of commuting and health care, and families are encouraged to downsize and move out of state as soon as their children graduate high school simply to survive. We need to be cutting taxes for seniors, helping them transition into and save for retirement, so they can stay here in New Jersey -- and that’s what my new bipartisan bill does.   My new bipartisan bill, The Senior Housing Improvement and Retirement Accounts (IRA) Act, will help seniors in retirement by reducing the taxes paid from the sale of their home and helping put those dollars into their retirement savings. Jonathan and Marcia Rieff represent the best of our state.  Jonathan was born down Route Four in Dumont. And when Jonathan and Marcia met and married – like so many New Jerseyans – they decided to come back to Bergen County to raise their family and live near where they work.  After 26 years, they've grown deep roots in their Glen Rock community, but while the Rieffs moved here for a better quality of life, for good jobs and great public schools, they cannot afford to live here in retirement. And they’re not alone.  New Jersey imposes the second highest state, local income tax burdens on families; we have the second slowest job market in America – only Alaska ranked lower.  And our ROI for all of those dollars has slipped; our roads are eight worst in the nation and our transit system was number one worst on time in the country last year.  While the Rieffs' story represents the best of our state, it also represents the worst part of New Jersey: it’s simply too expensive to live here. In New Jersey, we pay the highest property taxes of any state in the nation, according to the Tax Foundation. Not only that, New Jersey has the highest estate tax in the country.  Like so many New Jerseyans, the Rieffs’ financial advisors told them “look, the only way you get to retire is if you cut expenses.” So, now they are selling their home, despite what they’ll have to pay in capital gains taxes, just so they can afford to live and have enough to retire on.  We should be making it easier for families like the Rieffs to retire. We should be encouraging those who have helped make our communities great to stay here and retire here.  We shouldn’t be slapping seniors with outrageous taxes for trying to downsize their homes, making it even less affordable to live here.  My new bipartisan bill, The Senior Housing Improvement and Retirement Accounts (IRA) Act, will help seniors in retirement by reducing the taxes paid from the sale of their home and helping put those dollars into their retirement savings.  I’m hoping this legislation will be just what John, Marcia, and so many other families just like them need to stay put in the greatest state in the country, spending time with their families, listening to Bruce Springsteen and eating the best pizza in America.

Equifax—one of the nation’s largest credit reporting agencies—announced on September 7th, 2017, that it was the target of a cyber-hack affecting 143 million U.S. consumers.  The breach at Equifax took place between March and July and was discovered on July 29th, though an announcement to the public did not come for an additional 40 days. The magnitude of the security lapse and the delay between discovery and announcement to consumers and investors are of great concern to me.  This breach will have direct and lingering impacts to New Jersey consumers for years, including identity theft, higher credit costs, and even complete loss of access to credit.  This is unacceptable. To me, it's more Equi-scam than Equi-fix.   Today, from my seat on the Financial Services Committee, I am concerned twofold for New Jersey consumers: 1) that Equifax isn’t doing nearly enough to rectify the problems that they have created for consumers – that they are perhaps being negligent in their customer protection post-breach. And 2): that rather than rushing to rectify their security failure, high-level executives have allegedly engaged in insider trading.

I’ve had almost a hundred constituents call or write into my office on the Equifax scandal. Credit reporting is not usually a very popular topic, but the people of North Jersey are hurting. They are worried that their lives are ruined, that they won’t be able to rent an apartment, get a job, or even get access to government benefits like Social Security and medical care. One letter summed it up pretty concisely when they said “I have worked hard to build my credit and keep my personally identifiable information as secure as possible.” After all of that hard work, Equifax has screwed them.   The frustration is palpable in these letters. Many of them are stuck needing to use the credit-lock opt-out service at a monthly rate for all three credit reporting agencies. To quote another letter, “Hmmmm, let me think about this. It's going to cost me $60 per month ($20 for each agency) to protect the personal data that THEY should be protecting. Surely this is something Congress should be looking at. As a consumer, I don't have a choice but to allow these agencies to have my data. I believe that consumers should be able to opt out at no cost.”   Congress needs to know why the company’s efforts to date have been so inadequate. If it’s due to negligence, then they need to be held accountable. If it’s due to gaps in our laws, then we need to find solutions, because New Jerseyans are hurting.

Unfortunately, the tax hike bills delivers only one message: Drop Dead, New Jersey.
